data.title: Support roslyn analyzers and code fixes
data.body: It would be nice to have Roslyn analyzers and code fixes working in VSCode.

data.title: Consider changing "files.autoSave": "afterDelay" to "on"

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I've made this mistake myself and just saw another user do it as well.
When you copy the default "files.autoSave": "off" to user or workspace settings, the logical change is to set "files.autoSave": "on" if you don't read the fine print about setting it to "afterDelay".
I think this also makes sense with the other option "onSave".
We would have: "off", "on" and "onSave".
The default settings file comment will still call out tuning the "autoSaveDelay".

data.title: pressing tab adds spaces, but not as many as for a tab
data.body:
- make whitespaces visible and insert spaces for the tab key

``` json
{
    "editor.renderWhitespace": true,
    "editor.insertSpaces": true
}
```
- in the following code example place the cursor after the first tab
  ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6461412/13326469/5e38da76-dbe6-11e5-8b80-64ac5941690c.png)
- press `tab` key: **3 spaces** are inserted
  ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6461412/13326596/d65566dc-dbe6-11e5-8b3b-7f9b1b7d059d.png)
- revert the change and set the cursor after the second tab and press press `tab` key: **2 spaces** are inserted
  ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6461412/13326658/1ea61eb8-dbe7-11e5-935a-1fcfe55325e3.png)

I would expect that always 4 spaces are inserted

``` typescript
    for (var i = 0; i < editors.length; i++) {
            var editor = editors[i];
```

data.title: no whitespace shown at the end of a decorated line
Investigate use of ELECTRON_NO_ATTACH_CONSOLE for forked Electron processes in Windows
data.body:
We always thought that there was no way to `console.log` from an Electron process which is not launched from a command prompt. Doing so would throw since there was no stdout stream available. Ping @bpasero @dbaeumer @alexandrudima.

This would make it a hard task to setup the new `code` launcher in Windows too, related to #1704. Ping @Tyriar 

While investigating for #1704, I found out about `ELECTRON_NO_ATTACH_CONSOLE` from atom/electron#3692.

Using this flag would enable us to remove [this ugly code](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/bootstrap.js#L91). Needs investigation.

data.title: VS Code not working on Ubuntu when connected using XRDP.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Hi, it seems like the bug with either Atom or XRDP discussed in Atom issue here: https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/4360 is keeping VSCode from working in Ubuntu when you connect to it with RDP.
Trying to launch the app gives the following output: 

Xlib:  extension "XInputExtension" missing on display ":10.0".
Xlib:  extension "XInputExtension" missing on display ":10.0".
libGL: OpenDriver: trying /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/dri/tls/swrast_dri.so
libGL: OpenDriver: trying /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/dri/swrast_dri.so
libGL: Can't open configuration file /home/hannesne/.drirc: No such file or directory.
libGL: Can't open configuration file /home/hannesne/.drirc: No such file or directory.
libGL error: No matching fbConfigs or visuals found
libGL error: failed to load driver: swrast
bash: cannot set terminal process group (-1): Inappropriate ioctl for device
bash: no job control in this shell
Xlib:  extension "XInputExtension" missing on display ":10.0".
Xlib:  extension "XInputExtension" missing on display ":10.0".
[ , [Error: channel closed] ]

data.title: Value.replace is not a function
data.body:
from jackson davis:

I believe this is the commit that introduced this: b0fe390fa39cbf74a3dc123401c937f68de48ef9 to fix issue 1180

Isidor, this appears to be your change. Our launch options for C# and C++ support some object level properties in launch.json. Specifically, arrays of strings and arrays of name value pairs.  This was working back in December so. Now, the json parser for launch.json generates a new object that then the parser calls replace on. Since this isn’t a string, that throws an exception and fails the launch.
Example from our launch schema:

“customLaunchSetupCommands”: [{“text”:”target-run”, “description”: “run target”, “ignoreFailures”: false}]

Callstack:

Value.replace is not a function
System.Variables.AbstractSystemVariables.__resolveString
Array.map
System.Variables.AbstractSystemVariables.__resolveArray
System.Variables.AbstractSystemVariables.resolve – (debugConfigurationManager.js:261

data.title: I want to be able to just close things consistently without worrying about what type of thing it is
data.body:
There's this extremely annoying distinction between editor, working files and other views (e.g. settings). With a single, common shortcut key, if I have a thing open, I want to be able to close it and it's gone. If it was in working files, it's gone from there too. It doesn't matter what I had open, I want it gone. Screwing around trying to learn the different ways to close things and having to maintain a mental note of whether I'm closing an editor or a working file is irritating to the point that it's keeping me away from VS Code. The fact is, if I close a working file, getting it back with CTRL+P is so easy and frictionless that I don't even care that I closed it. If I could just have a shortcut key to "just close whatever the hell is currently open and, if applicable, remove it from working files too", that would be fantastic.

For what it's worth, I don't really care about the whole debate around tabs-or-not. Working files is fine for me in this regard. Saving the previous workspace state of a working file, even if it gets closed, is a pretty good idea though.
